<@U0KPFAZNF> how would I “roll back” to a tag to restart from there ?
First, small background
Git really only consists of various "heads" which are a series of changes
Each point has a sha
Something like a tag or a branch are really just pointing at one of those shad
Shas
Tags a fixed to one sha. Branches move with the latest sha in a stream of commits
I see
But, you can arbitrarily repoint them any time you want
so I can look up sha by tag and get reset to that ?
Precisely
this is cool… I’m getting something out of this (sorry for you though :wink: )
So there's really nothing special about "convergence" other than it points to a stream that presumably relates tithe convergence effort
ok
You could say "git reset --hard v0.6.0-preview", and now your "convergence" branch is actually v0.6 ;)
This is both powerful and dangerous
So wield with the same respect as "rm -rf"
Anyway, the main point here is that the "heads" can exist independently from how you chose to keep track of them
understood
So all we are doing is setting little bookmarks in case we want to go back
as long as I use this as a temporary workspace just to go throgh the list I don’t care what I call the branch
right
i think this is all understood at this point, but to complete the thought
this is what we had the other day

so, the work we did on 0002 was still “there”, but there were no references to it for us to find it again
(this referenceless stream would be cleaned up the next time git runs garbage collection, btw)
if we happened to know the sha of “009”, we could get back to it
that is all the tagging is doing, is letting us save those
